tagline: Dolgobinda Paricha vs Nimai Charan Misra & Others on 27 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: h. i. was admissible under s. 32 ( 5 ) of the indian evidence act. the high court relied on ex. 1, a petition dated november 2, 1917, which. s. v. 2 and p. w. 4 supported the respondents'case as to the rightness of the pedigree.

tagline: M/S. Maharana Mills (Private) Ltd vs The Income-Tax Officer, ... on 14 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: indian income - tax officer may rectify any error apparent from record. the appellant, a private company, was assessed for rectification of the order under s. 35 of the act, 1922. appellant challenged the order to rectified the order's written down value of the fine - tax act.

tagline: Kaushalya Devi And Ors. vs Bachittar Singh And Ors. on 8 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: order of deputy custodian general with respect to cancellation of allotment was set aside. the facts may be briefly summarised in order to understand how this controversy arose. order does not seem to have been implemented till the beginning of 1952. in village budhewal, non - sitting allottees would have to be restored.

tagline: Mahant Ram Saroop Dasji vs S. P. Sahi, Special ... on 15 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: mahant ram saroop dasji made an application in the high court under art. 226 of the constitution praying inter alia requested a writ quashing the order of the bihar state board of religious trusts requiring the appellant to submit a return of income and expenditure under s. 2 ( 1 ) of the act does not include within its ambit private and public trusts recognised by hindu law.

tagline: The State Of Bihar & Others vs Sm. Charusila Dasi on 15 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: a deed of trust was executed by the respondent in march 1938 when she was residing at d in the state of bihar. in the trust deed she described herself as the settlor, and it was recited therein that she had installed a deity named iswar srigopal in her house and had been regularly worshiping and performing the puja of the said deity.

tagline: Sardar Sarup Singh & Others vs The State Of Punjab & Others on 1 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: in 1925 the sikh gurdwaras act, 1925, was amended in 959, a board had been constituted, called the sikh act, 1959. under s. 43 of the act, the act was amended by the act of 1959, in order to extend the act to the area which was formerly within pepsu. in addition to the members of the board, the board consists of three categories of elected members, and ( 3 ) co - opted members, which included persons residing in pepsu and others.

tagline: M/S. Sasa Musa Sugar Works (P) Ltd vs Shobrati Khan And Others on 29 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: m / s sasa musa sugar works sued for per - mission to dismiss workmen's application under s. 33a of the act. the workmen were suspended for taking part in a protracted go - slow in contravention of the industrial disputes act. a few days later, it served similar notices on 15 others and suspended them.

tagline: Ujagar Singh vs Mst. Jeo on 23 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: ujagar singh's cousin is accused of using a custom custom to prove her brother's property. the high court held that the appellant had proved the custom set up by her. the judge held in favour of an appellant but high court reversed their decisions holding that no such custom was made.

tagline: The Commissioner Of ... vs Husenali Adamji And Co on 21 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: the respondent company was a dealer in matchwood called sawar. logs were despatched the same by rail from chanda and other stations in the central provinces to ambernath, a town in the erstwhile province of bombay. cl. 2 reserved the right of the consignee to examine the goods on arrival at ambernath.

tagline: The State Of Ajmer (Now Rajasthan) vs Shivji Lal on 22 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: the state of ajmer ( now rajasthan ) asked for a job if the complainant paid him rs. 100. the high court acquitted him on the ground that he was not a public servant. the state appealed to the supreme court on appeal. he was acquitted on both the charges, but on appeal, high court found that he did not deserve to be held guilty on both of the charges.

tagline: Om Prabha Jain vs Gian Chand & Another on 1 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: petition against impersonation of the people act in 1951 is an order under s. 116a. words " secretary to the election commission " were put in against the name of the person on whose behalf money was paid. appellant contended that the receipt showed that the money had been paid by the respondent acting for secretary to election commission.

tagline: Ram Dial vs Sant Lal And Others on 23 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: petition filed by the respondent no. 1 on the ground of corrupt practice - mandate to voters by religious leader - undue influence - representation of the people act, 951. a large number of voters of the constituency were namdhari sikhs and the appellant, under the authority of the supreme religious leader of the namdharis sikhs and his son, issued the following poster.

tagline: Ghulam Mehdi vs State Of Rajasthan on 21 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant ghulam mehdi, dost mohammad and raghubir singh all took to produce salamat ali whenever and wherever he was required. the appellant was sentenced to six months'imprisonment in civil jail. appellant's bail bond was executed by three sureties.

tagline: The Management Of Ranipur ... vs Bhuban Singh And Others on 21 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: industrial dispute - standing orders - interpretation of - enquiry includes proceedings before industrial tribunal - industrial disputes act, 1947. standing orders were concerned with employers and employees and not with tribunals. the company was granted permission to dismiss the workmen's applications under s. 33a of the act.

tagline: Ram Gopal vs Anant Prasad And Another on 21 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant was the holder of a permit to run stage carriage - application for renewal. appeals court cancelled appellant's permit and granted the permit to the respondent. the appellant then moved the judicial commissioner for a writ of certiorari quashing the order of appellate tribunal.

tagline: The State Of Bihar & Others vs Bhabapritananda Ojha on 15 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: india's president of bihar state board of religious trusts has served a notice on the respondent's handling of the temple. the responseent made an application under art. 226 of the constitution to the high court of patna challenging the validity of the action against him on the grounds that the bihar legislature did not have legislative competence to deal with the temple in question.

tagline: Andheri Marol Kurla Bus Service& ... vs The State Of Bombay on 21 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: conciliation proceedings were started in january 1952 with respect to some disputes between appellant 1 and its workmen. the appellants and three others were prosecuted under s. 31 of the industrial disputes act, 1947, for a breach of s. 33 for. dismissing a workman during the pendency of the conceliation. proceedings had terminated on the expiry of 14 days and the dismissal was, therefore, not during the. pencetion proceedings.

tagline: Din Dayal Sharma vs The State Of Uttar Pradesh on 23 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant was committed to court of session for trial of offences under s. 5 ( 2 ) prevention of corruption act, 1947 and 161 indian penal code. section 10 of the criminal law ( amendment ) act, 1952, transferred only cases pending before magistrates to special judges but did not transfer cases which had been committed before the act came into force.

tagline: The Patna Electric Supply Co., ... vs The Patna Electric Supply ... on 23 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: patna electric supply workers'union date of judgment in patna, india. union's claim and directed company to start construction of 15 quarters, as specified by the government scheme, within a year. tribunal upheld the claim, saying the appellant company must provide quarters to its employees in terms of the bihar government scheme.

tagline: Bhagwan Singh vs Rameshwar Prasad Sastri & Others on 14 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant's plea inter alia was that he executed the contracts not in his individual capacity but as the mukhiya of the village. the appellant had an interest in contracts for execution of works undertaken by the bihar government. the election was challenged under s. 7 ( d ) of the representation of the people act, 951.

tagline: Ramanlal Mohanlal Pandya vs The State Of Bombay on 21 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: the complainant met the appellant at the railway station and was going to anand. complainant complained that he needed to pay a sum of rs. 100 but the complaints dragged on and nothing happened till june 17, 1954 when there was a talk of a settlement and compounding complaints.

tagline: Chandrika Prasad Tripathi vs Shri Siv Prasad Chanpuria & Others on 9 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellant made an applica - tion alleging that there was non - compliance with the provisions of s. 117 inasmuch as ( i ) the deposit was not in favour of the secretary to the election commission, and ( ii ) the amount was refundable to the depositor and would not be payable to appellant in case the petition was dismissed under s. 90 ( 3 )

tagline: Management Of Balipara Tea Estate vs Its Workmen on 30 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant is the owner of balipara tea estate in assam. the appellant company had dismissed him for misconduct, after holding a regular inquiry against him. appellant's duties included the preparation and maintenance of leaf weighment book and daily wages book. the paper was meant to contain a record of the remuneration earned by a female labourer.

tagline: Salekh Chand And Anr. vs The State Of Uttar Pradesh on 22 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellants salekh chand and baboo ram were convicted under section 7 of the essential supplies act 1946. they were sentenced to 6 months'rigorous imprisonment and a fine of rs. 500 / - each, or default to suffer further rigorous imprisonment for 6 months. the sessions judge of meerut dismissed the appeal, and the application in revision to the allahabad high court was dismissed summarily.

tagline: Textile Supply Co., Assam vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 7 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: judgment bhagwati, j. 1, of the indian income tax act ( xi of 1922 ) was entered into between nine partners, rameshwarlal ajitsaria, son of mahadeolal himatsingka deceased representing the firm of ghasiram dwarkadas, gauhati, of no. 43 / 44.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs Patel & Co. on 22 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: judgment bhagwati, j. 1, was the larger firm of patel & co. constituted by a deed of partnership dated the 6th february, 1948. the firm was registered by the income - tax officer by singh's order dated the 11th june, 1951, stating that the partners had applied for registration.

tagline: In Re: The Berubari Union ... vs Reference Under Article 143(1) ... on 1 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: pakistan raised the question of berubari for the first time in 1952 alleging that under the radcliffe award it should form part of east bengal and was wrongly included in west bengal. the president of india referred the matter to the supreme court under art. india's president made the award on january 26, 195o, and it has since been governed on that basis.

tagline: Ranjit Singh vs The State Of Punjab on 21 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: a habeas corpus application was made to the high court alleging that one s. was illegally arrested and kept in unlawful custody without obtaining remand from a magistrate. by way of a return the appellant, a sub - inspector of police, filed a false affidavit controverting the allegations made in the application. he was prosecuted and convicted under s. 193 penal code.

tagline: Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar ... vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 14 April, 1959
summarized_judgment: judgment bhagwati, j. 1, is directed against the refusal by the high court of patna. the appellant converted his said proprietary business into a private company. the company was subscribed for by way of consideration for the said transfer 25, 000 shares of the company.

tagline: Messrs. Calcutta Company Ltd vs The Commissioner Of ... on 12 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: bhagwati, natwarlal h. das, sudhi ranjan ( cj ) hidayatullah, m. satyatullah ( m. citation ) claimed a deduction of the said sum of rs. 24, 809 in calculations of the deeds of sale. the appellant sold plots and received a portion of the sale price.

tagline: Tahsildar Singh And Another vs The State Of Uttar Pradesh on 5 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: two persons were killed on the spot in uttar pradesh. one was shot dead and two others were killed. the culprits and seven others were sent up for trial for the offence. the defence alleged that prosecution had developed its case. the case is expected to be heard later this month.

tagline: The Union Of India vs Kishorilal Gupta And Bros on 21 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the respondents entered into three contracts with the appellant, for the fabrication and supply of diverse military stores, each of which contracts contained an arbitration clause. by the last of these settlement contracts the respondents agreed to pay to appellant certain moneys in settlement of disputes relating to the first two original contracts. they failed to create the hypothecation.

tagline: The Management Of Hotel Imperial, ... vs Hotel Workers' Union on 21 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellants, who were managements of the three hotels, decided to dismiss some of their workmen. they were found guilty of misconduct as a result of enquiries held by them and suspended them without pay. the appeals were held without pay pending the receipt of the permission of the industrial tribunal under s. 33 of the act.

tagline: Associated Hotels Of India Ltd vs R. N. Kapoor on 19 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the respondent made an application for standardisation of rent under s. 7 ( 1 ) of the delhi and ajmer - merwara rent control act, 1947 ( 19 ) and the rent controller of delhi fixed the rent at rs. 9, 600 in four quarterly installments, which was later reduced to rs. 8, 400 by mutual agreement.

tagline: The Associated Cement Companies ... vs Its Workmen & Another on 5 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the associated cement companies ltd., dwarka cements their workmen & another date of judgment. gajendragadkar, p. b. das, sudhi ranjan ( cj ) bhagwati, natwarlal h. das and rf 1972 were among those to be fined for their part in the industrial dispute.

tagline: British India General Insurance ... vs Captain Itbar Singh And Others on 11 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: a suit claiming damages for negligent driving was filed aginst the owner of a motor car, who was insured against third party risks. it contends that the defence available to it was not restricted to the grounds enumerated in s. 96 ( 2 ) of the act relied on the conditions of the policy as a defence.

tagline: The Lord Krishna Sugar Mills ... vs The Union Of India And Another(And ... on 6 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: petitioners challenged constitutionality of sugar export promotion act, 958. impugned act imposed the following restrictions on owners of 40 factories producing sugar by the vacuum pan process. petitioners say it was not permissible to take the notification issued under another statute into consideration. the act was enacted for the purpose of exporting sugar with a view to earning foreign exchange.

tagline: The Indian Molasses Co. (Private) ... vs The Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 5 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: hidayatullah, m. sinha, bhuvneshwar p. kapur, j. m. benchmarker and the indian molasses co. ( private ) ltd. trustees took out a policy, where a certain sum of money was paid per annum. the trustees took to hold the said sums upon trust to spend the same in taking out a deferred annuity policy with an insurance society.

tagline: B. N. Nagarajan And Ors vs State Of Karnataka And Ors. Etc on 3 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: in the new state of karnataka ( karnatake ) it came into existence on 1 - 11 - 56 as a result of integration of the areas which formed part of erstwhile states of bangalore, madras, coorg, bombay and hyderabad. but in the merged states, there was a non gazetted class designated as graduate supervisors in the madras state and as supevisors in the indian state. but on 15, 167 more persons of the same class were promoted as officiating assistant engineers.

tagline: The Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs Ranchhoddas Karsondas, Bombay on 8 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: a public notice under s. 22 ( 1 ) of the income - tax act, 1922 was published on may 1, 1045. the assessee submitted a voluntary return showing an income of rs. 1, 935 for the assessment year 1945 - 46. the assessment was made within one year of the notice. the inspector of the office of income tax, bombay v. and the assar syndicate, ignored the voluntary return and issued a notice.

tagline: The New Jehangir Vakil Mills Ltd vs The Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 12 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the high court held that the monies related back to the receipt of the cleques at bhavnagar amounted to receipt of. the sale proceeds from the cheques by the assessee. the court asked the lower court to submit a full statement of case on points, which were never raised by the parties nor decided by the income tax authorities or the tribunal.

tagline: The Central Bank Of India vs Their Workmen(And Connected ... on 12 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: ' no banking company shall employ any person whose remuneration takes the form... of a share in the profits of the company,'said labour appellate court. the labour appellate tribunal took the view that s. 10 of the act did not stand in the way of granting bonus to bank employees.

tagline: Narayandas Bhagwandas Madhavdas vs The State Of West Bengal on 7 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant was arrested and released on bail with a direction to appear before the magistrate on september 19. the appellant went to dum dum aerodrome to board a plane for hong kong. appellant's search by customs authorities a sum of rs. 25, 000 was recovered from him which he had not declared in his declaration form.

tagline: Guest, Keen, Williams Private Ltd vs P. J. Sterling And Others on 15 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: a dispute was raised by the workmen as to the validity of such retirement. the labour appellate tribunal on appeal held that the standing order in question could not bar adjudicate the aging workmen. it was urged on behalf of the respondents that the age of superannuation should apply only to new entrants and in the case of old ones.

tagline: The Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs Kalu Babu Lal Chand on 15 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: r was the karta of the hindu undivided family who became interested in a business concern which was then being carried on by others. r had 326 ordinary shares and his brother 356 shares. r was a private company with limited liability, in which of the total 950 ordinary shares, r was 326 shares. it was claimed that under indian companies act a hindu family cannot.

tagline: Saroj Kumar Mazumdar vs The Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 4 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellate assistant commissioner of the hindusthan co - operative insurance society, in appeal, held that the transaction was an adventure in the nature of trade. an appeals court reversed the decision and overturned the findings and the appellate court reversed its findings. an appellate tribunal on appeal reversed the ruling and the decision was overturned.

tagline: The Trustees Of The Charity ... vs The Commissioner Of ... on 5 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: trustees of the charity fund founded by sir sassoon david in bombay. they must apply to poor and indigent members of the jewish community of bombay. trustees must apply less than half of the income for the benefit of the members of jewish community. the aim is to apply to the poor, indigents of jewish or any other indian community of india.

tagline: Messrs. Lalchand Bhagat Ambical ... vs The Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 14 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellant's food grains licence was cancelled for the accounting year for its failure to keep proper stock accounts. appellant was prosecuted under the defence of india rules but had been acquitted for the benefit of doubt. an appellant had filed - its income - tax return showing a loss of rs. 46, 4i5 in the business.

tagline: Messrs. Shalimar Works Limited vs Their Workmen on 8 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the company closed the works indefinitely and notified all those who applied for reengagement were not retaken. a majority of the workmen applied for being retaken, but those applied after that date were refused. the labour appellate tribunal upheld the order of reinstatement in respect of 15 workmen only.

tagline: Maharajadhiraj Sir Kameshwar ... vs The State Of Bihar on 15 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: an appellant showed a sum of rs. 2, 82, 192, which he had paid to the tekari rai for two lease - hold properties. the assessee appealed and the commissioner of agricultural income - tax reversed the said decision. the district of bihar moved the board of revenue and the district appealed.

tagline: C.S. D. Swamy vs The State on 21 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant was put up on trial on charges under s. 5 ( 3 ) of the act, 1947. payments of particular sums by way of bribe were not proved against him. high court holding that the appellant's bare statements from the dock unsupported by any other acceptable evidence could not satisfactorily account for large deposits standing to his credit in his bank accounts.

tagline: Ahmedabad Manufacturing And ... vs Comissioner Of Excess Profits ... on 14 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: a total of 53 employees admitted 2, 45, 550 to the benefits of provident funds'scheme. the total amount was disallowed under rule 12 of sch, i 3, 82, 240 " total amount of benefit payments " was in a attached list.

tagline: Umacharan Shaw & Bros. vs Commissioner Of Income-Tax, West ... on 15 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: judgment hidayatullah, j. 1. two appeals against an order dated june 1, 1956, of the high court of judicature at calcutta in income - tax reference no. 10 of 1956 and an order of the appellate assistant commissioner of income tax confirming an order declining to register the appellant firm under section 66 ( 2 ) of the act, hereinafter referred to as the act.

tagline: Pares Nath Thakur vs Smt. Mohani Dasi And Others on 12 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the plaintiffs brought the suit out of which the present appeal was based on a fictitious document based on deed of trust upheld by decyeeholder - deed, if fraudulent in character - burden of proof - concuyyent findings of lact - power of high court in second appeal - code of civil procedure o. 21, yr. 60 of the code was erroneous.

tagline: Shri V. V. Giri vs Dippala Suri Dora And Others on 20 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: shri v. v. giri and others date of judgment in a double member of a scheduled tribe. the petition was based on three grounds, viz., that s2 was properly and validly declared elected. s1, s1 was declared elected to the general seat and s2 had received the largest number of votes out of remaining candidates.

tagline: The Indian Hume Pipe Co., Ltd vs Their Workmen on 5 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant manufactured hume pipes and had factories in different parts of india, pakistan and ceylon. the appellant claimed deductions as prior charges on account of losses suffered on the lahore factory written off. appellant had issued debentures in 1942 - 43 redeemable in 1962 - 63.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs Messrs. P. M. Rathod & Co on 20 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the respondents were manufacturers of perfumery and hair oils at ratlam in madhya bharat which at the relevant time was a part b state. they were ordered to be delivered to customers against payment - concessional rate of taxation applicable to part b states. the participants were assessed to income - tax, in respect of profits from such sales of goods to customers in part a and c states and the payments were also received there.

tagline: Shri Jagdish Mills Ltd vs The Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... on 12 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: shri jagdish mills and bhagwati natwarlal h. das, sudhi ranjan ( cj ) hidayatullah. the appellant was paid for payment by cheque cheques by british india - post office. they received and accepted them in baroda in full and unconditional satisfaction of its claim.

tagline: Naresh Chandra Ganguli vs The State Of West Bengal And ... on 20 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellant was detained under s. 3 ( 1 / 2 ) of the pre - ventive detention act, 1950 ( 1 ) of 1950 ( 2 ) ( 1. 2 ) stated that he was acting in a way prejudicial to the maintenance of public order. the high court on an application under ss. 491 and 561a of the code of criminal procedure for the issue of a writ of habeas corpus.

tagline: Phulbari Tea Estate vs Its Workmen on 6 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: workmen das and another were arrested by the police on the complaint of the appellant company for an alleged theft. das said he had nothing to say and knew nothing about the theft. the company came up in appeal by special leave to the supreme court, where it raised the question of competency and competency.

tagline: M/S. Titaghur Paper Mills Co. Ltd vs Its Workmen on 5 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: in 1949 the workmen raised industrial disputes claiming profit bonus for the years 1950 - 51 and 1951 - 52. in 1953 the workers raised wage for each increase of 460 tons upto 36, 000 tons and for 2 days, basic wage for every 46o tons produced upto a maximum of 36, 00 tons. but the appellate tribunal awarded profit bonus equal to one month's basic wage.

tagline: The Graham Trading Co. (India) Ltd vs Its Workmen on 7 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant had been paying puja bonus for its workmen continuously from 1940 to 1952 at rate of one month's wages. the appellant contended that payments in the past years had been ex gratia. but they were entitled to the payment because it was a customary and traditional payment.

tagline: Jnanendra Nath Ghose vs The State Of West Bengal on 8 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellant was tried on a charge of murder by the sessions judge with the aid of a jury. the trial - misdirection - approver - reliability - corroborated the approver's evidence connecting the accused with the crime. the jury found him guilty and the session judge accepted the verdict sentenced him to life.

tagline: Messrs. Ispahani Ltd. Calcutta vs Ispahani Employees Union on 6 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: m / s. ispahani ltd., which transferred its registered office from calcutta to chittagong. the appellant company was incorporated in the good - will and trading rights of m. m. amhani ltd and other workmen agreed to the termination of their services with the same workmen on the same basis.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income Tax, Bihar ... vs M/S. Patney & Co on 5 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the respondents were acting as agents of two firms in bombay and madurai, in british india, for the supply of certain goods to the nizam's government. the amount cheques were sent to the respondents at secunderabad, and when received, they were credited in their books and crediting to their account.

tagline: Shri B. P. Hira, Works ... vs Shri C. M. Pradhan Etc on 8 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: workers were employed as timekeepers in the time office of the central railway workshop and factory, parel, bombay, claimed overtime wages under the payment of wages act, 1936 ( 4 of 1936 ) the validity of the claim on both grounds was disputed by appellant. only four of the respondents, who were required to do the work of progress timekeepers, could claim the status of workers within the meaning of s. 2 ( 1 ) of the act.

tagline: Krishan Kumar vs The Union Of India on 21 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellant was employed as an assistant store keeper in the central tractor organisation, delhi. he took delivery of a consignment of iron and steel received by rail for the organisation and removed them from the railway siding. appellant claimed his conviction was bad as the prosecution failed to prove he converted the goods to his own use and that he had not done so.

tagline: Tika Ram And Sons Ltd. vs Its Workman (Bishamber Dayal) on 1 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant was employed as a munim ( accounts clerk ) by the appellant from october 25, 1948 to august 31, 1951. an order has been passed directing appellant to reinstate respondent in his old job with continuity of service and to pay him subsistence allowance and pay as specified in the award.

tagline: Abdul Rahim Ismail Rahimtoola vs The State Of Bombay on 14 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant's contention was that s. 3 of the indian passport rules, 1950, were ultra vires the constitution. on a reasonable interpretation of the constitution bench,. 3 and 4 of the rules did not apply to an indian citizen. the appellant was rightly convicted.

tagline: Messrs. Kamarhatty Co. Ltd vs Shri Ushnath Pakrashi on 21 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: application under s. 33a of the industrial disputes act, 1947. inter alia said there was no reason for retrenchment on account of closure of shop. the appellant company was granted special leave to appeal. the application was rejected by the appellate tribunal. but the appeals court refused permission to re - instatement.

tagline: M/S. Sarupchand Hukamchand & Co vs Union Of India And Others on 5 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: an unregistered firm treated as registered under s. 23 ( 5 ) of the act. the income - tax officer treated the firm as'resident and ordinarily resident'the firm was not satisfied and moved both the income tax officer and appellate assistant commissioner 987 found to have incurred a loss in the first assessment years.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income-Tax, ... vs M.K. Kirtikar on 7 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: judgment das, c. j. 1 is an appeal by special leave from the order of the high court of judicature at bombay passed on september 22, 1955. the firm used to pay to each of its three employees, including the respondent, a commission of one per cent. on its total annual turnover in its colour department in addition to their salaries.

tagline: Great Indian Motor Works Ltd.,And ... vs Their Employees And Others on 6 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: supreme indian motor works ltd. and auction - purchaser not aggrieved by the award - winning auction - buyingr. the company's employees were refused sanction to appeal by the high court. an appeals tribunal dismissed the appeal in limine as incompetent in view of the provisions of the companies act 1956.

tagline: Crompton Parkinson (Works) ... vs Its Workmen And Others on 6 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellant agreed to pay to parent company 5 % of the net value of its sales every year as service fee for the use of their patterns, valuable designs, benefit of research and ancillary services and facilities. appellant was a 100 % subsidiary of the british company, crompton parkinson ltd.

tagline: The Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd vs Its Workmen And Others on 5 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: in resisting the workmen's claim for bonus for the year 1955 - 56 appellant claimed that it was entitled to 4 % interest on the depreciation reserve used as working capital. in calculating gross profits for the purpose of the full bench formula the following items of income should be excluded.

tagline: The Manager, Hotel Imperial vs The Chief Commissioner And Others on 13 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: industrial dispute between hotel and its workmen was referred to an industrial tribunal. it was on the form of order of reference, the main contention was incompetent. the order was merely for the sake of convenience so that tribunal may know whom it should give notice when proceeding to deal with the reference.

tagline: Commissioner Of Income Tax, Bihar ... vs M/S. Patney & Co on 5 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: the respondents were acting as agents of two firms in bombay and madurai, in british india, for the supply of certain goods to the nizam's government. the amount cheques were sent to the respondents at secunderabad, and when received, they were credited in their books and crediting to their account.

tagline: Charan Singh vs The State Of Uttar Pradesh on 14 May, 1959
summarized_judgment: charan singh, appellant herein, convicted of killing sarjiti, 10 or 12, in her house in village anta - ki - garhi, police station sadabad, in 1957. the appellant also filed an appeal, accepted the reference and affirmed the conviction and sentence.

tagline: Anil Starch Products Limited vs Ahmedabad Chemical Workers' ... on 5 May, 1959

summarized_judgment: a strike in public utility service, which was clearly illegal, could also be justified. the law does not contemplate such a position nor is it warranted by any distinction made by the industrial disputes act, 1947. it should be clearly understood by workmen who participated in such a strike that they cannot escape liability for such.

tagline: N. R. Ghose Alias Nikhil Ranjan ... vs The State Of West Bengal on 27 October, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellant pleaded the bar of s. 403 code of criminal procedure on account of his acquittal by mr. dutta gupta. a complaint was filed against the. appellant and bose before the sub - divisional magistrate, darjeeling. under the w. b. criminal law amendment ( special courts ) act, 1949, was approved by high court.

tagline: M. Narasimhachar vs State Of Mysore on 12 October, 1959
summarized_judgment: narasimhachar was the first woman to be elected to parliament. she is the latest in a string of attempts to reach the country's top supreme court. the case is expected to be heard at the end of this year's hearing on the issue of the state of india.

tagline: B.K. Pal Chaudhry vs The State Of Assam on 7 October, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellant is a medical doctor and at the material time, he was the civil surgeon of dibrugarh. he was a witness in a criminal case being g. p. case no. 654 / 54 in which three persons were charged inter alia under s. 376 of the indian penal code with the offence of rape.

tagline: Mst. Rukhmabai vs Lala Laxminarayan And Others on 17 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: a joint hindu family owned extensive properties and business. in 1915 certain members of the family executed a register deed of relinquishment in favour of another member. the trust was created in a sum of rs. 15, 000 for constructing a building or buying land therewith and paying the net income to the two beneficiaries in equal shares.

tagline: Ct. A. Ct. Nachiappa Chettiar And ... vs Ct. A. Ct. Subramaniam Chettiar on 13 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: ct. a. ct. nachiappa chettiar and others vs. respondent vs. the respondent against his brother and his sons, appellants 1 to 5 respectively. the court passed a preliminary decree excluding from its operation the aforesaid immoveable properties. but in his appeal the responders did not challenge the finding of the trial court.

tagline: State Of Bihar vs Gopi Kishore Prasad on 25 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: gopi kishore prasad's case to be heard at the old bailey. state of bihar says it's not clear what happened to the case. india's first state of the state to hold the case to the civil rights act. state's president calls for an end to human rights in the state.

tagline: All India Station Masters vs General Manager, Central ... on 20 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: the roadside station masters of the central railway challenged the constitutionality of promotion for guards to higher grade station masters'posts. petitioners contend that the channel of promotions amounted to a denial of equal opportunity as between roadside stations and guards in the matter of promotion. equality of opportunity in matters of employment can be predicated only 312 between persons who are either seeking the same employment.

tagline: State Of Jammu & Kashmir And Others vs Thakur Ganga Singh And Another on 26 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: thakur ganga singh and another date of judgment in the high court of jammu and kashmir. the respondents filed a petition in the supreme court of the jammu judgment. the petition is expected to be heard in the state of jammu & kashmir and others in the case. the case was brought in by thakur singh's family in the town of jammu.

tagline: S. M. Banerji vs Sri Krishna Agarwal on 20 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant held an office under the government and was dismissed from service for corruption or disloyalty to the state. the appellant was declared duly elected after a period of limitation. the application was rejected without making any enquiry. appellant had been dismissed from government service for a reason other than corruption.

tagline: Bharwad Mepa Dana & Another vs State Of Bombay on 10 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: the appellants were charged with having formed an unlawful assembly with the common object of committing the murder of three persons. the high court held that there were ten to thirteen persons in the unlawful assembly though the identity of the persons except four had not been established. they were acquitted of five - legality of common intent - no proof who gave fatal blows - effect of - indian penal code.

tagline: Shri Bhaskar Waman Joshi ... vs Shri Narayan Rambilas ... on 3 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: shri narayan rambilas agarwal, shri bhaskar waman joshi and others date of judgment. the deed dated september 10, 1931, described as a sale deed. the transferors were indebted and that to discharge the liability three items of immovable properties, described in the deed.

tagline: Y. Mahaboob Sheriff And Others vs Mysore State Transport ... on 6 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: the state transport authority passed orders renewing the permits of the petitioners for a period of one year from april 1, 1958, to march 31, 1959. the state government opposed such renewal and applied fresh permits for the routes in question might be granted to it as state government intended to nationalise the transport services.

tagline: The State Of Bihar vs Rat Bahadur Hurdut Roy-Mott Lall ... on 26 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: the respondent mills was carrying on business of manufacture and sale of gunny bags, hessian and other jute products at katihar. the state of bihar appealed to this court, saying it violated arts. the high court held that the proviso to s. 14a of the act was ultra vires the state legislature as it violates arts. 226 and 227 of the constitution.

tagline: Shrinivasa Reddy And Others vs The State Of Mysore And Others on 6 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: petitioners in writ petition no. 75 of 1959 were expiring on 31st march, 1958, and were renewed up to march 31, 959. state transport authority granted temporary permits to the petitioners till state transport department obtained - their permits. petitioners had also applied for renewal of their permits and rejected the renewal applications.

tagline: The Official Liquidators,U. P. ... vs Shri Rameshwar Nath Aggarwal on 10 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: the u. p. union bank was in occupation of a building belonging to the respondent as a tenant. after the passing of the winding up order of the bank the official liquidators removed the offices and called upon landlord to take possession of the premises. the company refused to take charge of the entire rent from the date of the order.

tagline: Narumal vs State Of Bombay on 25 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: india's state of bombay is the latest in a series of attempts to establish a colony in the indian ocean. the indian state of india is the first of its kind in the world to take the case to the supreme court. the case is expected to fetch more than £80, 000 in 2018.

tagline: Feroz Din And Others vs The State Of West Bengal on 25 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: a company dismissed from its service four of the appellants, for taking part in an illegal slowdown strike in the hot mill section of its works, which were a public utility service. on such dismissal the slow - down strike, however gained strength. the company issued a second notice dated april 25, stating that the workers who did not record their willingness to work the plant to their normal capacity.

tagline: The State vs Hiralal Girdharilal Kothari, ... on 30 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: three appeals arise out of three certificates granted by punjab high court in a criminal matter. they will be dealt with together as the point raised in them is common. there is a government printing press at rashtrapati bhavan printing press in new delhi. the proposals were divulged to d. p. chadda and others.

tagline: Jibon Krishna Mukherjee & Another vs New Bheerbhum Coal Co. Ltd. & ... on 10 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: the high court refused to entertain the appellant's applications under s. 51 of the code of civil procedure. the receiver entered into an agreement with respondent no. 2, a third party, for the sale of the property for a larger sum than the decretal amount on the condition that the sale was not to be confirmed.

tagline: The Okara Electric Supply Co. ... vs The State Of Punjab And Another on 13 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: the okara electric supply co. ltd. and another vs. respondent, have been granted sanction to a non - licensee to engage in the business of supplying energy to muktsar. on january 3, 1959, the first respondent issued a notice exercising the option of acquiring the undertaking in pursuance of the notice. the state of punjab and another date of judgment were issued in 1959.

tagline: Mohan vs State Of Uttar Pradesh on 5 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant was convicted by the sessions judge of budaun for the murder of one ram bharosey in 15 - 11 - 1957. on appeal the conviction and sentence were confirmed by the high court at allahabad. the appellant has now appealed to this court with special leave.

tagline: Dharamdas Hukamatrai Dorwani vs State Of Bombay on 4 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant dharamdas hukamatrai dorwani was charged with having committed an offence under section 420 of the indian penal code in that on or about march 22, 1953 he cheated chhotubhai nagarji desai by dishonestly inducing him to enter into and execute an agreement. the high court held that the charge had not been proved against the appellant beyond reasonable doubt.

tagline: The State vs Hiralal G. Kothari And Others on 30 November, 1959
summarized_judgment: case registered under s. 165a of the indian penal code, s. 5 ( 2 ) of the official secrets act, 1923. and s. 120b of indian code were filed against the persons involved and proceedings began before a magistrate on this complaint. the case was lodged in march 1956, and a case was registered under the d. c. of india's penal code.

summarized_judgment: a joint hindu family owned extensive properties and business. in 1915 certain members of the family executed a register deed of relinquishment in favour of another member. the trust was created in a sum of rs. 15, 000 for constructing a building or buying land therewith and paying the net income to the two beneficiaries in equal shares.

tagline: Hamdard Dawakhana (Wakf) Lal ... vs Union Of India And Others on 18 December, 1959
summarized_judgment: kapur, j. l. sinha, bhuvneshwar p. and kapur among those to date of judgment. the drugs and magic remedies ( objectionable advertisements ) act, 1954 ( 21 of 1954 ), was challenged on the ground of violation of fundamental rights it is necessary to impose reasonable restrictions.

tagline: Arun Ghosh vs State Of West Bengal on 2 December, 1959
summarized_judgment: arun ghosh was detained under s. 3 ( 2 ) of the preventive detention act, 1950. the appellant molested two respectable women and assaulted two other people. the question is whether a man has committed a breach of law and order, or has acted in a manner likely to cause a disturbance of the public order.

tagline: Anant Chintaman Lagu vs The State Of Bombay on 14 December, 1959
summarized_judgment: hidayatullah, m. benchmarked for murder by poisoning - circumstantial evidence - poison not detected in body of deceased - conduct of accused, both before and after - conviction for murder. court can unhesitatingly hold the death was not natural one.

tagline: Sardar Kapur Singh vs The Union Of India on 15 December, 1959
summarized_judgment: appellant was a member of the indian civil service posted in the punjab. appellant challenged the president's order under art 226 of the constitution. the appellant is accused of misappropriation and misdemeanour framed against him. the east punjab government suspended him and appointed the chief justice of east punjab high court as enquiry commissioner.

tagline: State Of Madhya Pradesh & Ors vs Shardul Singh on 2 December, 1959
summarized_judgment: india's constitution of india, art. 311 ( l ) was upheld by the president of india and the governor of a state to make rules regulating the conditions of service of persons appointed to the civil service of the union or the state's civil servant. the inspector - general sent a copy of the report to the respondent, who was the authority competent to dismiss him.

tagline: Hamdard Dawakhana And Anr., ... vs The Union Of India (Uoi) And Ors. on 18 December, 1959
summarized_judgment: petitions under art. 32 of the constitution raise the question of the constitutionality of the drug and magic remedies. they challenged the act because it contravened the provisions of art. the act passed on april 30, 1954, along with the rules made thereunder. the drug controller, delhi state stopped the sale of forty of their products set out in the petition.

tagline: Narendra Kumar And Others vs The Union Of India And Others on 3 December, 1959
